instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1465: What is A1465? A1465 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2924, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00164, 820-3208, 820-3435..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> keyboard fn not working
threads.message: I had messed with this before and thought I was done but apparently not (trackpad temp TSOP line bad). Although the keyboard viewer shows every key responding, the fn key doesn't work/register so the fn keys don't do their functions and the keyboard viewer appears different, showing a full size extended keyboard instead of the smaller 11".  Does anyone know which pin i should be looking at?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> keyboard fn not working
threads.message: fn is part of the complete keyboard matrix. This is a bad keyboard, but who uses fn anyway. I test fn by simply trying the F1 key to turn down brightness, when holding down fn that should not work.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> keyboard fn not working
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> keyboard fn not working
threads.message: no i tried a new keyboard and it does the same thing so its not the keyboard. brightness and none of those secondary functions work, that;s why i need to fix it

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> keyboard fn not working
threads.message:
This is a trackpad coding issue. There are 2 different keyboard matrix layouts. If you replace the trackpad you need to match it to the keyboard type. This can only be done in AST.
So either get a trackpad that matches your current keyboard or get a keyboard that matches your trackpad. Or take it to Apple to have them configure the trackpad.
Fixing the old trackpad may be the easiest option here, I bet it is just a damaged connector.
